awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer for Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Edward Merino from University of Cincinnati and colleagues Patrick Limbach, James Mack II and Neil Ayres have acquired a matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization, tandem time-of-flight, tandem mass spectrometer MALDI-ToF/ToF-MS/MS) equipped with multiple ionization sources. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. MALDI TOF combines gentle ionization (ideal for producing intact ions of peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, synthetic polymers, and other similarly sized species) with a detection mode that offers an excellent balance between sensitivity and accuracy across a wide mass range. This highly sensitive technique allows identification and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse students with this modern analytical technique. The instrument improves research projects from around southwestern Ohio. The Mass Spectrometry Facility analyzes samples from other universities and private companies. Thus, this new instrument answers new research questions derived from the local area. The instrumentation enables further growth in research that addresses wider research themes of biomaterials, chemical sensing and many other applications.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful in characterizing synthesized blood compatible biomaterials and for uncovering the chemistry and biology of reactive molecules. This mass spectrometer is used in the development of recyclable catalysts and reagents using mechanochemistry and in investigations of radiation-induced damage during translation in melanized fungi which is associated with a wide variety of infectious syndromes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
NSF Grant # 1828072 is titled MRI: Acquisition of a Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer for Research and Education. The funds used were to purchase an instrument that helped with both education, research and the broader community. During the funding period the Chemistry Department within the University of Cincinnati was able to use the instrument to increase scientific learning and increase job skills of students within the chemistry major. To accomplish this, the team developed lessions that intergrated the Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer in biochemistry, biophysical studies, and polymer science courses. The Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer helped the students by teaching them the molecular basis of physical interactions, the relationship of molecular size and chemical properties, and protein structure. Next, the Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer was used in research. One publication has been published and several are forth coming.. These manuscripts span topics including understanding the impact of cell stress on skin and how certain molecules, like RNA, change their modifications to survive. This grant also facilitated research in polymers and biosafe materials. Finally, the project was used to initiate science around the Cincinnati community. Several companies used the Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer to analyze proteins and plastics for various purposes. Overall, the impact of the Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer on the University of Cincinnati has been large and is still growing. In the near future, it is foreseeable that the instrument will produce more effects on the University of Cincinnati physical infrastructure. 

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2021
Modified by: Edward J Merino
